intro: Aegilops tauschii subsp. tauschii, commonly known as the intermediate wheatgrass, is a wild relative of modern wheat that plays a significant role in plant genetics. It is native to the Middle East and Central Asia and is characterized by its tall, slender stalks and spike-like inflorescence. This species is diploid, with a genome size that has contributed to its importance in wheat breeding programs. Its genetic material is used to improve wheat varieties for traits such as disease resistance and yield. The plant also serves as a valuable resource for studying the evolution of the Triticeae tribe.
